Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Coeur d'Alene Online Digital Resources

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Coeur d'Alene (ISO 639-3 crd/Salish, USA, henceforth CRD) is a language no longer spoken by children. Ethnologue classifies this language as nearly extinct, with only two elderly native speakers. However, the Coeur d'Alene community has a strong interest in revitalizing the language. Under the direction of locally controlled language programs, a number of community members have passed through the language programs. In spite of the fact that Coeur d'Alene was, in the early part of the 20th century, one of the best-documented Salish languages, the community has access to precious little of this documentary material. Over 1,200 pages of unpublished field notes and typed manuscripts, along with a number of audio recordings, have sat collecting dust over the years since their collection. Various dictionaries and grammars, all prepared before the digital revolution, have been available only to the most determined researchers, but not to community members. The research team, group including linguists and Coeur d'Alene community members, will develop an online digital archive (already in pilot) to (1) preserve and (2) make appropriately accessible some of this wealth of resources in formats that can be utilized by scholars and community members alike. Funding will be utilized to expand the number of resources beyond those already in the pilot archive, and to bring the entire web repository into line with best practices for web archiving of language data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Coeur d’Alene (ISO 639-3 crd/Salish, USA, henceforth CRD) is a language no longer spoken by children.  Ethnologue classifies this language as nearly extinct, with perhaps a handful of elderly native speakers.  The Coeur d’Alene  community has a strong interest in revitalizing the language, under the direction of locally controlled language programs.   In spite of the fact that Coeur d’Alene was, in the early part of the 20th century, one of the best-documented Salish languages, the community has access to precious little of this documentary material.   Over 1,200 pages of unpublished field notes and typed manuscripts, along with audio recordings, have sat collecting dust over the years since their collection.  Various dictionaries and grammars, all prepared before the digital revolution, have been available only to the most determined researchers, but not to community members.  Preliminary work had been carried out by PI Bischoff in consultation with the CRD language program’s former director to develop a series of test websites that (1) preserve and (2) make accessible some of this wealth of resources in formats.  Funding for this project was used to expand the number of resources included in this project, and to bring the entire web repositories into line with best practices as outlined in Bird and Simons (2003) and Chang (2010).

The resources created under this grant included the Couer d'Alene Online Language Resource Center (accessible at: http://lasrv01.ipfw.edu/COLRC/), as well as two workshops developed to support other endangered language communities explore accessible options for similar work, and several peer reviewed publications and conference presentations.  Most importantly, a collaboratively developed mission statement - involving project personnel and the CRD language program's director - guides the project for the foreseeable future.
